Step.name: Upcoming Toolkit Components
Step.html: The Forest Soil Disturbance Monitoring Protocol and the Soil Disturbance Field Guide are the current tools available to help as you continue to develop a robust soil monitoring program on your unit.

Step.name: Risk Ratings
Step.html:
It is important to know the inherent risk associated with different soils in the project area. Some soils may be prone to compaction, puddling, or wind erosion. As you start to review a unit it is important to identify the potential risks associated with the different soils.

Efforts are currently underway to develop a process to help each soil scientist identify the appropriate risk ratings.

Step.name: Decision Support-Tool
Step.html:
If you build it they will come ....

Currently the Decision Support-tool is being negotiated with the CIO to establish the necessary rules and protocols for this user interface that will help identify high priority units to conduct pre and post-treatment monitoring.

Step.name: Prioritize Assessment and Monitoring Units
Step.html:
Help! I have 2000 acres to monitor this summer and only enough funding to complete 500 acres with an aerial fly-by. What can I do?

The decision support tool is intended to help you identify the units that are higher priority for monitoring.

Step.name: Determining Detrimental Disturbance
Step.html: The question of detrimental disturbance must be evaluated in context with the soil risk rating and your regional soil quality standards. For example when evaluating if a site has soil displacement, consider the regional standards and how that soil displacement affects the long-term soil productivity of that specific site. If questions arise be sure to bring these forward to the regional soil scientist for guidance.

Step.name: Validation Protocol
Step.html:
For many years we have had soil quality standards which were a first approximation of the point that we could actually detect some change to the soil resource. You could consider the soil quality standards serving as a tool to identify potential problem areas and locations that would require more field study and mitigation measures to reduce the potential adverse impacts to the soil resource.

Our next step is to pursue opportunities for validation monitoring. Guidance on how to set up and conduct validation monitoring for soils will be included in additional soil monitoring toolkit updates. Consult your regional soil scientist if you are interested in more validation monitoring.
